Title: Text Truncation and Wrapping in .NET MAUI
Description:
Imagine an app without text; it would be practically non-functional, wouldn't it? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Text is an essential element in any application, and handling it appropriately according to different requirements is very important. In this article, we will focus on techniques for truncating and wrapping text using the LineBreakMode property to enhance the readability of our text. Let's get started! üöÄ

Let‚Äôs start!
What is the LineBreakMode?
This property allows you to control the wrapping and truncation of the text. Accepts an enumeration as a value, which contains the following values:
‚ûñ NoWrap
Its responsibility is to display only the text that fits on the device‚Äôs first line. This means the amount of text visible on the first line may vary depending on the size device. ‚Äì [It‚Äôs the default value].



‚ûñ WordWrap
These values automatically move text to the next line at the word boundary. This prevents words from being cut off at the end of a line, enhancing readability and allowing text to adapt to various screen sizes.



‚ûñ CharacterWrap
Unlike the WordWrap function, this setting automatically transfers text to the next line based on a character limit. This sometimes results in line breaks that do not align with entire words.




‚ûñ HeadTruncation
It omits the beginning of the text, presenting only the final part in a single line. It‚Äôs best used when the text‚Äôs conclusion is most relevant to the reader, ensuring focus on the most pertinent information.




‚ûñ MiddleTruncation
Unify the beginning and end of the text to fit within a single line, replacing the middle section with an ellipsis, which consists of three dots (...)



‚ûñ TailTruncation


It omits the end of the text, presenting only the initial part on a single line.








And our article is completed! ¬†.
Thanks for ready! üëã See you next time! üíöüíï
Spanish post:



‚ûñ https://es.askxammy.com/truncamiento-y-ajuste-de-texto-en-net-maui/
Reference:
‚ûñ https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/maui/user-interface/controls/label?view=net-maui-8.0?WT.mc_id=DT-MVP-50033

Title: Building a Text Editor: the Gap Buffer
Description: Prologue: The Agon 8-bit computer In December of 2022 I came across a new 8-bit computer called Agon. It was built around the eZ80 CPU, a modern version of the venerable Z80 processor that was popular in many 1980s microcomputers, and an ESP32 microcontroller for video generation using FabGL (now vdp-gl, a fork of FabGL maintained by me). The original Z80 was an 8 bit CPU with a 16 bit address bus, allowing it to access up to 64KiB of memory at a time.
